newsitem.title: CANADA: Hearing delayed in CWB complaint against railroads.
newsitem.headline: Hearing delayed in CWB complaint against railroads.

text.p: A hearing to determine whether Canada's two major railways were to blame for a backlog of grain-carrying vessels at Pacific ports earlier this year was delayed, a Canadian Wheat Board spokeswoman said.
The Canadian Transportation Agency, a federal quasi-judicial tribunal, was set to hear 41 submissions on August 11 on the backlog that the CWB says cost it C$15 million in demurrage charges.

But the CTA postponed the hearing to a yet-to-be-determined date after Canadian National Railway Co and CP Rail System filed a suit in Manitoba Court of Queen's Bench, CWB spokeswoman Tracey Bryksa said.
The railways alleged the CWB's external legal council was in a position of conflict of interest.
The railways tried to have the CWB's complaint to the CTA dismissed earlier this year and have maintained that shipment delays were due to heavy snowfall, extreme cold and equipment failure.
About 1.5 million tonnes of wheat sales had to be deferred to the 1997/98 (Aug/July) crop year because of the shipment delays, the CWB has said.
